entry.title: How To get compliant with iFlow Design Guidelines - Define Identifiers To Search In Message
entry.content:
Hello SAP experts,

I use the designguidelines when creating iFlows, but there is one point where I am unable to achieve compliance.

It concerns the following point in the Design Guidelines: Define Identifiers To Search In Message Processing Logs.

My current approach:

At the beginning of the iFlow, I have implemented a Groovy script that stores important values for identifying the customer in the CustomHeaderProperty.

Unfortunately, this does not seem to be enough to make me compliant with the Design Guidelines under ‚ÄòDefine Identifiers To Search In Message Processing Logs‚Äô.

Here is the Groovy script I used:

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;

def Message processData(Message message) {
    
	def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);
	if(messageLog != null){

		def sEquiID = message.getHeaders().get("EquiID");		
		if(sSapAuthenticatedUserName!=null){
			messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("EquiID", sEquiID);		
        }

		def sOrderID = message.getHeaders().get("OrderID");		
		if(sSapAuthenticatedUserName!=null){
			messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("OrderID", sOrderID);		
        }

	}
	return message;
}

 

Do you have any idea what else I need to do?

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Introducing Notifications in SAP Road Map Explorer: Stay Updated Effortlessly
entry.content:
Introducing Notifications in SAP Road Map Explorer: Stay Updated Effortlessly

We are excited to announce a new feature in the SAP Road Map Explorer that will improve how you stay informed about updates and changes: the notifications functionality.

The notifications functionality allows you to receive alerts directly within the SAP Road Map Explorer. This means you can react promptly and adjust your strategies without delay.

You can subscribe to notifications for the following elements:

  • Roadmap items
  • Saved roadmaps
  • Favorites
  • Collections
  • Business views

You will be notified when the following changes have occurred:

  • New data
  • Changed data
  • Deleted data

To check your current subscriptions:

  1. Click the "User" button in the top right corner.
  2. Navigate to "Notification Settings".

Here, you can see which categories you are currently subscribed to and manage your notification preferences.

To check which notifications you have received:

  1. Click the "Bell" button in the top right corner.
  2. On the left, you will see all notifications triggered based on the items you have subscribed to.

We believe this new feature will significantly enhance your experience with the SAP Road Map Explorer, making it easier than ever to stay informed and agile in your planning. Your feedback is invaluable to us, so please share your thoughts and experiences as you explore this new functionality.

Stay tuned for more updates and enhancements as we continue to improve the SAP Road Map Explorer to better serve your needs.

Contact us at any time via the email roadmaps@sap.com.

Your SAP Road Map Explorer Team

entry.title: Re: üì¢ Survey: ABAP Naming Conventions
entry.content:
Hi,

thanks for initiating the discussion and contributing!

"All the development artifact generators should refer to this config and propose names accordingly." from @Sivakumar_Subramaniam is an important point IMHO. Esp with the RAP generators, etc. I think this is an important point.

Besides this I would favor  more decentral approach and storing the definition together with the source code seems also a good idea to me.

IMHO different namings conventions could be in use even in one department, eg extending/enhancing existing solutions or creating new solutions could use different conventions.

Some central guidance on naming convention is of cource a good idea, but a rigid central approach to enforcing this dictator like seems not to be a good approach IMHO.

Regards,

 Wolfgang

entry.title: Re: üì¢ Survey: ABAP Naming Conventions
entry.content:
Hi @kilian_kilger, 

option 1 sounds better to me! There should be named sets of rules, to which a (ATC) check could refer. This way a run for package/software component A could use other rules than for B. The sets could even be transportable WB objects.

And imho its not a task of the compiler to check the rules. The compiler should only deal with things related to the language definition, i.e. syntax & sematics. Conventions are for lint-like tools.

But option 2 could be used by the development tools - if the editor knows which rules apply to the object shown, it could evaluate them ad hoc and mark deviations immediatly.

Regarding the persona question: The lead architect for the product is responsible at us.

BR, Holm

entry.title: Extending Standard SAP MDG Data Model (MM) with Custom Fields
entry.content:
This blog is based on our practical experience and learnings from a recent SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) project. We had a requirement to extend the standard SAP MDG Data Model (MM) with custom fields at both Plant and Sales levels.

To achieve this, there are two main approaches available:

  1. Traditional Approach
  2. In-App Extensibility

1. Traditional Approach : Using the traditional approach, adding a custom field requires multiple manual extensions across different layers of the SAP system ‚Äî including:

  • Database tables (e.g., MARC, MVKE)
  • CDS views
  • SOA services
  • OData APIs

During our implementation, while extending the MARC table with a custom field, we encountered the following error:

DBSQL_REDIRECT_INCONSISTENCY ‚Äì A table could not be redirected

SAP has already addressed this issue in SAP Note 2242679 ‚Äì Redirect inconsistency ‚Äì Proxy Substitution, which suggests executing the report NSDM_PROXY_SUBSTITUTION for the MARC table to adjust the related CDS view and resolve the inconsistency.

Although this resolves the immediate technical issue, the traditional approach still requires repetitive manual work ‚Äî extending the field individually at every layer (database, CDS, SOAP, and OData). This process is not only time-consuming but also prone to inconsistencies.

2. In-App Extensibility (Custom Fields and Logic)

To overcome these challenges, we adopted the In-App Extensibility approach using the Fiori app ‚Äî Custom Fields and Logic.

This approach allows you to add and manage custom fields in a single step. When a field is created via this app, it can automatically extend the following components (depending on your configuration and enablement):

  • Underlying database tables
  • Relevant CDS views
  • SOAP services
  • OData APIs

This provides a one-stop solution for extending standard SAP objects ‚Äî significantly simplifying the process and reducing development effort.

Extensibility Steps (Using In-App Extensibility)

Follow the steps below to create and enable a custom field using the Fiori App ‚Äì Custom Fields and Logic.

  • Open the Custom Fields and Logic app.

  • Click on the ‚Äú+ (Create)‚Äù button to add a new custom field.

Enter all the necessary information such as:

  • Business Context
  • Label
  • Data Type
  • Length

Select the services across different tabs where you want to make this custom field available (e.g., Database Table, SOAP Service, OData API, etc.). 

 

Click Save to save your configuration.

Click on Publish to enable the custom field.

The publishing process may take a few minutes. Once completed, the field‚Äôs status will change to ‚ÄúPublished.‚Äù

After publishing:

  • Check the database table (e.g., MARC or MVKE) to ensure the new field is added.

  • Verify that the field is available in the corresponding SOAP service.

  • Verify that the field is available in the corresponding MDC Model.

Note: The Data Model Extension process in MDG remains unchanged. You must still follow the standard MDG extension procedure as detailed in the official SAP document:https://www.sap.com/documents/2015/07/76525357-5b7c-0010-82c7-eda71af511fa.html

Key Takeaways

  • Traditional Approach: Requires manual extensions at multiple layers; higher maintenance effort.
  • In-App Extensibility: Provides a one-stop, upgrade-safe solution for extending database tables, CDS views, and APIs in a consistent manner.

Acknowledgment

Special thanks to Suresh, Soumya and Aswin for their valuable technical insights and contributions throughout the implementation.

entry.title: Re: To-Do Rematerialization is needed

Did you check the permission role for the user who wants to approve the workflow on the home page? You need to make sure that the 'Prevent Quick Approval of Workflow' is not checked in Manage Workflows. 

When this is checked, the user loses the ability to approve a workflow directly on the Home Page.

Henriette Beek

entry.title: Link Headless Storefront in GCP with API layer in SAP Commerce Cloud
entry.content:
Hi All,

We have a requirement where our API layer (OCC) is hosted in SAP Commerce Cloud (CCv2), while our headless storefront is deployed in Google Cloud Platform (GCP).

We‚Äôre aware of the standard connectivity approaches such as NAT or VPN to establish communication between CCv2 and external services. However, we‚Äôre exploring if there are any lower-latency or more private network options available.

For example, in Azure, something like Private Link could be used to connect securely to SAP CCv2 without routing over the public internet. Since our workloads are in GCP, we‚Äôre wondering if there‚Äôs any similar option or recommended best practice for achieving private or near-private connectivity between GCP and SAP CCv2.

Has anyone implemented such a setup or come across guidance on reducing latency and improving reliability when integrating GCP services with SAP CCv2?

SAP Commerce Cloud

entry.title: Re: IDoc message variant or function, what difference?
entry.content:
Thanks.

I did a quick investigation concerning the standard invoice process:

  • Inbound: IDoc type INVOIC02. Depending on MESCOD being FI or MM, the customizing (WE57/table EDIFCT) indicates that the inbound function module will be either IDOC_INPUT_INVOIC_FI or IDOC_INPUT_INVOIC_MRM. There is also a third value FKK / function module IDOC_INPUT_INVOIC_FKK.
  • Outbound: The output invoice customizing in message processing triggers the program RVADAUS1 (table TNAPR where KAPPL = 'V3' and output type = 1/print form), which generates the outbound IDoc, but I can't see how it fills MESCOD; by default I would say that it's empty (after reading the code), the only possibility to fill it with FI or MM would be to use the customer exit EXIT_SAPLVEDF_001 or the method CONTROL_RECORD_OUT_PREPARE of the BAdI SD_INVOICE_IDOC_OUTPUT. Weird. Probably I missed something.

RSEOUT00 is for outbound, in my case I generate inbound IDocs directly. I can't find "split by one" in RSEOUT00, what is it?

One more hint to confirm that it's a "personal flavor" as you say, I can find in WE57 (table EDIFCT) that SAP has used MESCOD for containing either FI or MM for INVOIC02, but has used MESFCT for containing either MM or SD for SPCORD01/SPCSTS01.

entry.title: End-to-End Garnishment Management in SAP: From Master Data to Calculation
entry.content:
Managing garnishments in payroll is a complex process that requires precision, compliance, and the right tools. For organizations operating across multiple jurisdictions, understanding the nuances of garnishment handling is critical to ensuring accuracy and legal adherence.

Join us for an in-depth session designed to equip SAP functional and technical professionals with a clear understanding of garnishment processing. This webinar will cover the complete lifecycle of garnishments - from master data configuration to calculation logic - illustrating how SAP solutions address even the most complex customer requirements.

Key Topics:

  • Types of Garnishments: Understand the legal and business classifications, including simultaneous garnishments and priority handling.
  • Calculation Scenarios: Explore how SAP handles payroll splits, retroactive pay, and garnishment cancellations with real-world examples.
  • SAP Features & Enhancements:
  • Discover the latest capabilities in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll, including garnishment calculation engine

Speakers:

entry.title: IBP file-based integration with SFTP server via Integration Suite - Cloud Integration (part 1)
entry.content:
Hello Community

The following blog entry will detail how to

  • Configure Integration Suite to use a Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) server in CI‚Äôs SFTP adapter,
  • Build an integration flow extracting data from IBP, transforming it within CI and storing it into a file on a server.

Unlike when using CI-DS and especially its on-premise agent for file-based integration, the Cloud Connect cannot store data. Hence the SFTP server is the way to go for an IBP to file (and file to IBP) integration.

 

Prerequisites

  • An SFTP server was created and made available,
  • The BTP/IBP Technical setup was executed,
  • As well as the Integration Suite Initial Configuration to start building your integration flows.

 

Configure the usage of an SFTP server via CI‚Äôs SFTP adapter

There are multiple steps that needs to be done in order to use an SFTP server for file-based integration using CI.

Required steps at a glance:

  • Get an SFTP server
    • Gather your Host, Port, User and Password
  • Configure the SAP Cloud Connector (SCC)
    • To reach the SFTP server you will most likely need to use SAP Cloud Connector if the server is located on your internal network and not exposed to the internet.

On Cloud Connector you have to create a new Cloud to On-Premise connection. When creating a new connection, you need to provide the host and port data. Optionally, you can specify a virtual host to use in CI - it is advised to use this option to keep a short, easy to use host name. E.g. settings:

Once the SCC is configured, the SFTP server must be reachable, which can be checked using the button.

If the check is successful, you can continue with the CI side settings. To do so, you first need to get the hostkey data. Navigate to Monitor -¬ª Integrations and APIs -¬ª Manage Security -¬ª Connectivity tests.

On the connectivity test screen select SSH and provide the required information:

  • Host = Virtual Host configured on SCC
  • Port = Virtual Port configured on SCC
  • Proxy-Type = On-Premise
  • Location ID = location ID of the SCC

As there are no credentials yet, select no authentication and Send the request. If successful, the hostkey information will be shown on the same screen:

Use the Copy Host Key button to copy the data to your clipboard, and create a new text file by pasting it in. Name the file as knownhost for practical reasons.

The next step is to provide the security material, navigate to Monitor -¬ª Integrations and APIs -¬ª Manage Security -¬ª Security Material.

In this step we have to trust the host key just copied, and we have to provide the authentication data.

First, choose Upload -¬ª Known Hosts, and upload the file that have just been created with the host key information.

Next, create new user credentials:

After completing these steps, the SFTP server can be used in SFTP adapters.

 

 

Configuring the iFlow for an IBP to SFTP server integration

The idea of this flow will be to read Product master data from IBP, transform the data by populating an IBP attribute based on the values of multiple input attributes and save this in a file stored on your SFTP server.

You can start by creating your iflow from scratch (1) within your own working package or by copying/uploading from the ‚ÄúIBP Read ‚Äì Example‚Äù iflow delivered by SAP from you ‚ÄúSAP IBP ‚Äì Reusable Integration Flows Example‚Äù package (2).

 

Other option is to copy the reusable iflow delivered by SAP for IBP Read (limitation: you will not be able to change its ID) or download it and upload it in your own package.

 

 

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

These are the steps that you need to keep in your iflow to extract data from IBP and write it in a csv file format that will be stored on your SFTP server:

 

  • Content Modifier function to set your iflow‚Äôs IBP data extraction related parameters,
  • External Call of type Request Reply to call the IBP destination by invoking SAP reusable iflow ‚ÄúSAP_IBP_Read_-_Initialize‚Äù via ProcessDirect,
  • Content Modifier function to fetch the initialization call to IBP output for the iflow log,
  • External Call of type Request Reply to extract the data from the IBP destination by invoking SAP reusable iflow ‚ÄúSAP_IBP_Read_-_Fetch_Data‚Äù via ProcessDirect,
  • Message Mapping function to detail how field mappings and data transformations should happen based on IBP xml format output,
  • Converter function of type XML to CSV Converter in order to save your output file in a csv format with separators as IBP output will be in XML,
  • External Call of type Send to push extracted and transformed data into a file on the identified SFTP server via the ad hoc SFTP receiving adapter,
  • Content Modifier function to set your iflow‚Äôs IBP closing parameters,
  • External Call of type Request Reply to close the IBP destination connection by invoking SAP reusable iflow ‚ÄúSAP_IBP_Read_-_Close‚Äù via ProcessDirect.

This example will focus on extracting and storing Product master data type data from IBP.

 

Content Modifier to pass IBP parameters

Set all relevant parameters needed to connect to IBP and extract the right data in the message Body section (check my previous blog entry with the list of mandatory parameters).

 

Process Direct to SAP_IBP_Read_-_Initialize

This step initializes the call to the IBP system.

 

Content Modifier Save Initialize Parameter

This step saves initialization parameters for IBP in order to feed them for the closing step.

See details in ‚ÄúIBP Read ‚Äì Example‚Äù iflow delivered by SAP from you ‚ÄúSAP IBP ‚Äì Reusable Integration Flows Example‚Äù package.

 

Process Direct to SAP_IBP_Read_-_Fetch_Data

This step extracts the required data from the IBP system.

 

Message Mapping function

Once you‚Äôve added this function to your flow, you need to click on it and select Create. Then, set a name for the mapping step.

Next, you need to specify your data structure for the source and target message.

You need to specify the XSD schema here for you output IBP XML data. There are multiple ways to build this including by running an example IBP data read iflow and fetching the payloads from logs. In this example the data read is the Product master data and it should look like this:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<xsd:schema xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"

            elementFormDefault="qualified">

  <xsd:element name="IBPReadMasterDataPRODUCT">

    <xsd:complexType>

      <xsd:sequence>

        <xsd:element name="item" maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0">

          <xsd:complexType>

            <xsd:sequence>

              <xsd:element name="PRDID" type="xsd:string"/>

                                             <xsd:element name="ABCID" type="xsd:string"/>

                                             <xsd:element name="PRDDESCR" type="xsd:string"/>

                                             <xsd:element name="MATTYPEID" type="xsd:string"/>

                                           <xsd:element name="UOMID" type="xsd:string"/>

                                           <xsd:element name="PRDFAMILY" type="xsd:string"/>

                                             <xsd:element name="PRDSERIES" type="xsd:string"/>

            </xsd:sequence>

          </xsd:complexType>

        </xsd:element>

      </xsd:sequence>

    </xsd:complexType>

  </xsd:element>

</xsd:schema>

 

Note that the XSD schema can be easily built using LLM.

You can save this and adjust the elements to your needs, as a .xsd file. The source and target don‚Äôt necessarily have to be the same, in my example I have more attributes in the output (file as target) rather than input (IBP extracted data) because I will use transformation logics to fill out the extra attributes.

Message Mapping is a graphical tool that lets you create mappings without any coding. Unlike the other mapping options, it is natively integrated into the CI interface. You can build a message mapping by simply dragging and dropping connections between source and target fields, and optionally adding functions between them to transform the data.

Note : You MUST link not only the individual attributes but also the structure headers like in our case ‚ÄúIBPReadMasterDataPRODUCT‚Äù and ‚Äúitem‚Äù.

Next for any data transformation or more complex mappings, you can leverage the standard CI functions.

In this example, I wanted to set a Product Family value as file output only based on the values of two input attribute values for ABC ID and Material Type ID.

If Material Type ID = FERT and ABC ID = A, then Product Family = Valuable. Else Product Family = Standard.

 

Another example set here is to use another extra target attribute to set a counter for the output file.

Once you are satisfied with your mapping configuration, you can simulate its execution without having to run the entire iflow.

 

For this you‚Äôll need an input file with testing data, in XML format which you can build from scratch, LLM or fetch from the iflow payloads (only available if you activate the trace for the logs).

If your simulation runs smoothly, you can proceed with the rest of your iflow steps.

 

Converter function of type XML to CSV

If your goal is to store the data in a csv file, you need to convert the extracted IBP data (XML format) using this ad hoc function.

In the processing tab of the function‚Äôs properties, identify the XML element that must be read to fill the file‚Äôs fields, the one that holds the IBP attribute values in other words, in this case : ‚Äú/IBPReadMasterDataPRODUCT/item‚Äù. This was already visible in your XSD structure and XML testing file previously in the mapping step.

 

Send to server via SFTP adapter

This step will connect to the SFTP server via the previously configured information. At this stage, provide the following information in the Target tab

  • Directory = SFTP server folder name
  • File Name = the file name with extension (.csv) to be created, you can also use the append timestamp to add automatically a suffix with date/time
  • Address = Virtual Host : Port, as configured on SCC
  • Proxy-Type = On-Premise
  • Location ID = location ID of the SCC
  • Credential Name = Name from the user credentials created earlier in CI.

 

Content Modifier Set Close Parameters

This step leverages the previously saved initialization parameters for IBP for the closing step.

See details in ‚ÄúIBP Read ‚Äì Example‚Äù iflow delivered by SAP from you ‚ÄúSAP IBP ‚Äì Reusable Integration Flows Example‚Äù package.

 

Process Direct to SAP_IBP_Read_-_Close

This step closes the IBP connection.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Once this is full iflow is configured, you can deploy it and follow the execution in the Monitor section.

With a successful execution, you should be able to find your output file in the SFTP directory and verify the content: Product master data extracted attribute values (Product Id, Description, ABC code, Material Type and UoM) and extra attributes that I only added in the target mapping structure like the Product Family string (Valuable / Standard) and Product Series counter.

 

Next blog entry

Next blog entry will cover the back integration: from file-based csv to IBP.

 

Sources

  • IBP Reusable integration flows - list and details
  • Configure-sftp-receiver-adapter

entry.title: Re: What are the best practices for migrating data from l...
entry.content:
Migrating data from legacy CRM systems into SAP CRM or SAP CX (Customer Experience, formerly SAP C/4HANA) is a complex process that requires careful planning and execution. Here are the best practices:

 

1. Assessment & Planning

  • Inventory existing data: Identify all customer, contact, lead, opportunity, and transactional data in the legacy system.
  • Define migration scope: Decide which data is essential, archival, or obsolete.
  • Understand target structure: Map legacy fields to SAP CRM/CX objects, noting any differences in data models.

2. Data Cleansing

  • Remove duplicates, incomplete records, or outdated information.
  • Standardize formats for names, addresses, phone numbers, and custom fields.
  • Ensure data quality to avoid ‚Äúgarbage in, garbage out.‚Äù

3. Data Mapping & Transformation

  • Create a data mapping document detailing source fields, target fields, and transformation rules.
  • Handle differences in picklists, codes, and mandatory fields.
  • Consider custom transformations for complex objects (e.g., historical transactions or loyalty points).

4. Choose Migration Tools

  • SAP Data Services, LSMW (Legacy System Migration Workbench), or SAP Cloud Platform Integration for automated migration.
  • ETL tools like Talend, Informatica, or custom scripts if the legacy system is non-SAP.

5. Test Migration

  • Perform multiple rounds of test migration using subsets of data.
  • Validate data accuracy, relationships, and completeness.
  • Involve business users for verification and sign-off.

6. Migration Execution

  • Perform migration during low-activity periods to minimize disruption.
  • Monitor logs for errors or failed records.
  • Have a rollback plan in case of critical failures.

7. Post-Migration Validation

  • Validate records, workflows, and CRM functionality.
  • Reconcile migrated data with legacy totals (number of accounts, contacts, opportunities).
  • Train users on any differences in data structure or fields.

8. Documentation & Governance

  • Document mapping, transformations, and exceptions for auditing and future reference.
  • Establish ongoing data governance to maintain quality after migration.

entry.title: Best Practices for Training Custom Invoice Templates in SAP Document AI (Base Version)
entry.content:
üìò Summary:

Looking for best practices on how to handle schema updates and reuse trained templates in SAP Document Information Extraction (DOX) Base Version. After adding new fields through schema versioning, previous training and mappings are not retained. Need guidance on whether retraining is required or if there‚Äôs a migration/reuse option.

Scenario:

I‚Äôve been working on a custom invoice extraction setup using SAP Document Information Extraction (DOX) ‚Äì Base Version (non-generative).
The use case involves 500 invoices with different layouts.

I created:

  • One custom schema

  • Around 100 templates, each trained manually with ‚ÄúSetup Type = Manual‚Äù for all fields

  • Training done successfully for ~100 invoices

 New Requirement:

Later, we received a request to add 5 new fields to the existing schema.
However, DOX doesn‚Äôt allow adding fields to an active schema version that already has templates.
To add new fields, we must:

  1. Deactivate and delete the existing templates, or

  2. Create a new schema version

I proceeded with creating a new schema version and added the new fields.

 Challenge:

When uploading invoices using the new schema version, the existing training/mappings from version 1 are not available.
It behaves as a completely new schema ‚Äî none of the previously trained fields or templates are reused.

 Question / Clarification Needed:

Do I need to retrain all 500 invoices again for the new schema version, or
Is there any recommended approach or migration method to reuse the field mappings from the previous version?

üöÄ Discussion Points / Best Practices (to confirm with SAP team):

  • Is there any way to migrate or copy field mappings between schema versions?

  • What‚Äôs the best practice when new fields need to be added to a schema with multiple templates?

  • Should we plan all required fields before starting training to avoid versioning issues?

  • Does SAP DOX Premium (Generative AI) handle such cases more flexibly?

entry.title: Solution Order Simulation APIs - OData V4
entry.content:
Table of Contents

  • Table of Contents
  • Introduction
  • Authentication and Access
  • Metadata
  • API Capabilities and Entities
  • BusinessSolutionOrder ‚Äì Solution Order Header
  • BusSolnOrdPartner ‚Äì Solution Order Header Partner
  • BusSolnOrdItmPartner ‚Äì Solution Order Item Partner
  • BusSolnOrdItmPriceElement ‚Äì Item Price Element
  • BusSolnOrdItmBillgReqItem ‚Äì Item Billing Request Item(Contract Item)

 

Introduction

Solution Order is a business transaction in SAP Cloud ERP, used to sell solutions which can be a combination of either physical goods, one time services, recurring services, subscriptions, or projects bundled as one integrated customer offering. With the 2508 release of SAP Cloud ERP,  the OData V4 APIs for simulation of solution order is available. Simulation APIs can be used to simulate various entities of solution order without creating a solution order. Various determination logic like partner determination, price determination, billing plan etc can be simulated without creating a solution order. This can be used to provide a quote using a quoting engine outside of SAP Cloud ERP. Such external quoting solutions can benefit from the possibility of quoting a real time price calculated in SAP Cloud ERP using the Solution Order simulation APIs.  In this blog, you will find more information about the API, the entities available for consumption and the operations on these entities.

 

Authentication and Access

The communication arrangement with the Business Solution Order Integration scenario(SAP_COM_0706) needs
to be in place to access the API. You will need to create a communication arrangement for the communication scenario
SAP_COM_0706, A communication system with an inbound user. You can as well configure OAUTH 2.0 if
needed.

The API supports Basic Authentication(username/password), OAUTH2.0, and X.509 Certificate Authentication

 

Metadata

Metadata provides a description of the service, detailing the structure of the data, available entities, their
properties, relationships, and supported operations. It acts as a blueprint that allows both developers and tools
to understand how to interact with the service without needing prior knowledge of its design.
It can be accessed using the below URL
https://<<SERVER>>/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_bussolnordsimulation/srvd_a2x/sap/api_bussolnordsimulation/0001/$metadata
Below is a screenshot, with a part of the metadata of the Business Solution Order API.

In the above partial view of the metadata, you can see the Entity BusinessSolutionOrderItem, it has 2 key fields - BusinessSolutionOrder and BusinessSolutionOrderItem, a set of properties like Product, Quantity, BusSolnOrdItmCategory, etc. it also specifies the type, max length, precision etc of the properties. There are a set of navigational properties(or associations) for the entity. Associations are other entities related to the current entity.

 

API Capabilities and Entities

EntitySupported OperationsDescriptionAssociations
BusinessSolutionOrderCREATE (Simulate)Solution Order Header

_Item

_Partner

BusinessSolutionOrderItemCREATE (Simulate) only using deep insert on BusinessSolutionOrderSolution Order Item

_BusinessSolutionOrder

_Partner

_PriceElement

_BillingRequestItem

BusSolnOrdPartner
CREATE (Simulate) only using deep insert on BusinessSolutionOrderHeader Partner_BusinessSolutionOrder
BusSolnOrdItmPartner
CREATE (Simulate) only using deep insert on BusinessSolutionOrderItem Partner

_BusinessSolutionOrder

_Item

BusSolnOrdItmPriceElement
CREATE (Simulate) only using deep insert on BusinessSolutionOrderItem Price Element

_BusinessSolutionOrder

_Item

BusSolnOrdItmBillgReqItemCREATE (Simulate) only using deep insert on BusinessSolutionOrder

Billing Request Line of a Contract Item

_BusinessSolutionOrder

_Item

 

BusinessSolutionOrder ‚Äì Solution Order Header

Simulate solution order with one item to get header and item entities with simulated net value

You can add any number of items to simulate.

POST <host> /sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_bussolnordsimulation/srvd_a2x/sap/bussolnordersimulation/0001
/BusinessSolutionOrder

X-CSRF-Token: abc
{
  "BusSolnOrdType": "SOLO",
  "BusSolnOrdDescription": "Simulation Demo",
  "SoldToParty": "17100001",
  "PayerParty": "17100001",
  "PaymentTerms": "0001",
  "SalesOrganization": "1710",
  "DistributionChannel": "10",
  "Division": "00",
  "RespEmployeeBusinessPartnerId": "9980000549",
  "_Item": [
    {
      "Product": "TG11",
      "Quantity": 1,
      "BusSolnOrdItmQtyUnitISOCode": "PCE"
    }
  ]
}

 

BusSolnOrdPartner ‚Äì Solution Order Header Partner

You can pass an empty _Partner:[] entity in the payload to read the header partners that are determined based on the partner determination procedure assigned to the solution order transaction.

POST <host> /sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_bussolnordsimulation/srvd_a2x/sap/bussolnordersimulation/0001
/BusinessSolutionOrder

X-CSRF-Token: abc

{
  "BusSolnOrdType": "SOLO",
  "BusSolnOrdDescription": "Simulation Demo",
  "SoldToParty": "17100001",
  "PayerParty": "17100001",
  "PaymentTerms": "0001",
  "SalesOrganization": "1710",
  "DistributionChannel": "10",
  "Division": "00",
  "RespEmployeeBusinessPartnerId": "9980000549",
 
  //Empty Partner association in payload to return the simulated entity in response
  "_Partner":[],
  
  "_Item": [
    {
      "Product": "TG11",
      "Quantity": 1,
      "BusSolnOrdItmQtyUnitISOCode": "PCE"
    }
  ]
}

 

BusSolnOrdItmPartner ‚Äì Solution Order Item Partner

Similar to header partner, You can pass an empty _Partner:[] entity in the payload to read the item partners that are determined based on the partner determination procedure assigned to the item category.

POST <host> /sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_bussolnordsimulation/srvd_a2x/sap/bussolnordersimulation/0001
/BusinessSolutionOrder

X-CSRF-Token: abc

{
  "BusSolnOrdType": "SOLO",
  "BusSolnOrdDescription": "Simulation Demo",
  "SoldToParty": "17100001",
  "PayerParty": "17100001",
  "PaymentTerms": "0001",
  "SalesOrganization": "1710",
  "DistributionChannel": "10",
  "Division": "00",
  "RespEmployeeBusinessPartnerId": "9980000549",
  "_Item": [
    {
      "Product": "TG11",
      "Quantity": 1,
      "BusSolnOrdItmQtyUnitISOCode": "PCE",
      
      //Empty Partner association in payload to return the simulated entity in response
      "_Partner": []
    }
  ]
}

You can also override a partner determined in simulation by passing the updated partner in the payload. This can be useful to for example simulate changes in shipping cost based on the address of a new partner that is passed which is different from the determined partner. 

POST <host> /sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_bussolnordsimulation/srvd_a2x/sap/bussolnordersimulation/0001
/BusinessSolutionOrder

X-CSRF-Token: abc

{
  "BusSolnOrdType": "SOLO",
  "BusSolnOrdDescription": "Simulation Demo",
  "SoldToParty": "17100001",
  "PayerParty": "17100001",
  "PaymentTerms": "0001",
  "SalesOrganization": "1710",
  "DistributionChannel": "10",
  "Division": "00",
  "RespEmployeeBusinessPartnerId": "9980000549",
  "_Item": [
    {
      "Product": "TG11",
      "Quantity": 1,
      "ShipToParty": "17100002",
      "BusSolnOrdItmQtyUnitISOCode": "PCE",
      
      "_Partner": [
        {
          "CustMgmtPartnerFunction": "00000055",
          "CustMgmtBusinessPartner": "17100002"
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}

 

BusSolnOrdItmPriceElement ‚Äì Item Price Element

Similar to partners, You can pass an empty _PriceElement[] entity in the payload to read the item price elements that are calculated based on the pricing procedure assigned.

How ever you can also pass a new price element in simulation request like a discount to simulate the solution order with the discount condition

POST <host> /sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_bussolnordsimulation/srvd_a2x/sap/bussolnordersimulation/0001
/BusinessSolutionOrder

X-CSRF-Token: abc
{
  "BusSolnOrdType": "SOLO",
  "BusSolnOrdDescription": "Simulation Demo",
  "Language": "EN",
  "SoldToParty": "17100001",
  "SalesOrganization": "1710",
  "DistributionChannel": "10",
  "Division": "00",
  "RespEmployeeBusinessPartnerId": "9980000549",
  "_Item": [
    {
      "Product": "TG12",
      "Quantity": 1,
      "BusSolnOrdItmQtyUnitISOCode": "EA",
      
      //Adding a fixed discount
      "_PriceElement": [
        {
          "ConditionType": "DRV1",
          "ConditionRateValue": -10,
          "ConditionCurrency": "USD"
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}

 

BusSolnOrdItmBillgReqItem ‚Äì Item Billing Request Item(Contract Item)

Billing Request Line item is relevant for a service contract item of type SOSC(Service Contract Item) and SOPA(Service Contract Item with Price Adaptation). You can simulate the billing plan by providing the billing date and settlement period in the payload and you will see the Billing Request Items accordingly. For example if you provide a settlement period as monthly for a contract running for 1 year, you will see 12 Billing Request Items in the simulation response.

POST <host> /sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_bussolnordsimulation/srvd_a2x/sap/bussolnordersimulation/0001
/BusinessSolutionOrder

{
  "BusSolnOrdType": "SOLO",
  "BusSolnOrdDescription": "Simulation of BRLs",
  "SoldToParty": "17100001",
  "SalesOrganization": "1710",
  "DistributionChannel": "10",
  "Division": "00",
  "RespEmployeeBusinessPartnerId": "9980000549",
  "_Item": [
    {
      "BusinessSolutionOrderItem": "10",
      "Product": "SRV_CONTRACT",
      "BusSolnOrdItmCategory": "SOSC",
      "Quantity": 1,
      "QuantityUnit": "AU",
      "BusSolnOrdItmQtyUnitISOCode": "C62",

      // Billing date first of the month
      "SrvcMgmtBillgPlanBillgDateRule": "BILL0002",
      // Settlement period - monthly billing
      "SettlementPeriodRule": "BILL0001",

      "ServiceContrItemStartDateTime": "2025-08-13T00:00:00Z",
      "ServiceContrItemEndDateTime": "2026-08-13T00:00:00Z",
      "_BillingRequestItem": [],
      "_PriceElement": []
    }
  ]
}

entry.title: SAP Cloud ALM with SAP Analytics Cloud - Pre-Built "Project Analytics" Dashboard
entry.content:
Are you aware of the SAP Cloud ALM APIs available for projects that can be used to create custom dashboards? Whether you are seeking a customized view for your daily project analysis or you are here out of curiosity, welcome! There is something in this blog for everyone.

On one hand, we have SAP Cloud ALM, which provides access to project data through APIs, covering areas such as requirements, tasks, defects, .... On the other hand, we have SAP Analytics Cloud, which enables the creation of custom dashboards to visualize and analyze this data. By combining data from SAP Cloud ALM with SAP Analytics Cloud, you can develop dedicated dashboards that offer comprehensive insights into project management activities.

Previously, I showcased pre-built dashboards, "Health Analytics" and "Real User Analytics," utilizing data from SAP Cloud ALM Operations in SAP Analytics Cloud. -> Ready-to-Use Template Dashboards: Integrating SAP ... - SAP Community

This time, I want to show you a new pre-built dashboard "Project Analytics", using the data from Implementation part of SAP Cloud ALM.

 

Can you tell me more about this new pre-built dashboard?

The "Project Analytics" dashboard leverages multiple APIs from SAP Cloud ALM, with each API dedicated to specific project elements, such as requirements, tasks, defects, and more. By creating a separate model for each API, I've integrated these data streams into a cohesive dashboard. This approach allows for a comprehensive view of project implementation, combining diverse data points into informative visualizations tailored to enhance project analysis and decision-making.

This pre-built dashboard shows an example of what you can have in SAP Analytics Cloud by using the APIs of SAP Cloud ALM Implementation. It can be use as it is if it suits your needs. But if you are more interested in specifics elements like "Defects" and not that much into "Tasks", it can be customized to focus on your needs. It can be used as a starting point of discussion. This adaptability ensures that the dashboard meets your unique requirements. 

 

What charts does this pre-built dashboard contain?

The "Project Analytics" dashboard is structured to give both an overview and detailed insights into your project implementation. Here's a breakdown of the dashboard sections:

Project Selection and Date Display:

  • At the top right of the dashboard, you can select from the available projects. In this demo, two project data sets are included. Selecting a project synchronizes all charts to show data specific to that project.
  • To the top right again, the date of the data being viewed is displayed. All models in this dashboard get data automatically from SAP Cloud ALM once daily, each morning, this is the default setup for this dashboard.

Project and Element Overview:

  • The second row provides a summary of the project and its key elements, offering a general view without delving into specifics. This includes the total number of items within the project.

  •  It also presents an overview of the status of features and defects, with multiple iterations of similar charts, because why not?

Detailed Element Analysis:

This section offers a more granular look at certain elements, with a focus on Requirements and Tasks for this demo.

Requirements:

  • You have one chart that illustrate the evolution of items created over time.
  • Some numbers that compare item creation on a weekly and monthly basis, demonstrating possible analytical calculations.
  • A chart which shows the distribution of requirements by status and priority, offering a snapshot of the project's current state.
  • A comparison between confirmed requirements this week and last week provides insight into project progress.

 Tasks:

  • You can see a graph which displays the daily evolution of tasks, broken down by status to observe trends and changes.
  • Then on the right is a table showcasing that beyond numbers, Cloud ALM also provides detailed item information. While this demo includes a few columns, additional details like descriptions and assignees can also be displayed and used on others type of charts.

This pre-built dashboard provide both high-level summaries and detailed analyses. It also showed you some capabilities of integrating data from SAP Cloud ALM projects into SAP Analytics Cloud.

 

How to have it on my SAP Analytics Cloud tenant? 

The installation/customization of the "Project Analytics" dashboard is a service provided by SAP. If you're interested in obtaining this dashboard, whether in its current form or customized to meet your specific needs, please reach out to your SAP representative. 

 

Thank you

entry.title: Boosting Business Efficiency with SAP S/4HANA and Cloud Integration
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs fast-paced digital era, organizations must continuously adapt to new technologies to stay competitive. One of the most powerful solutions enterprises are turning to is SAP S/4HANA, an intelligent ERP platform designed to deliver speed, flexibility, and real-time business insights.

However, the real potential of SAP S/4HANA is unlocked when it‚Äôs integrated with cloud computing. This combination not only streamlines operations but also enhances scalability, security, and data accessibility across the organization.

1. Why SAP and Cloud Integration Matters

Integrating SAP systems with the cloud allows businesses to access data anytime and anywhere, without relying solely on on-premise infrastructure. Moreover, cloud models help reduce IT costs by minimizing hardware investments and system maintenance, as most of the management is handled by the cloud provider.

2. Key Benefits for Enterprises

  • Real-time data access: Enables faster and more accurate decision-making.

  • Business process automation: Reduces human errors and increases efficiency.

  • Enhanced data security: Cloud storage offers advanced encryption and protection.

  • Flexible scalability: System capacity can easily adjust to business growth.

3. Real-World Success Stories

Many global organizations implementing SAP S/4HANA in the cloud have reported up to a 30% increase in operational efficiency. They also benefit from faster analytics, improved data visibility, and stronger collaboration between departments.

A Quick Note on Innovation Across Industries

Innovation doesn‚Äôt just drive the corporate world ‚Äî it‚Äôs also transforming entertainment and online experiences. A great example is zeusbola a modern digital entertainment platform that continues to evolve through technology and user-focused design.

Just as SAP revolutionizes how enterprises manage data, ZEUSBOLA is redefining how digital platforms deliver fun, safety, and seamless user experiences in the entertainment industry.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Release 2022 & Higher Release (HCM)
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì Human Capital Management - Solution Strategy

 

As SAP SuccessFactors remains the primary focus of SAP‚Äôs HCM innovation, there are no plans for major additional functionalities or re-architectures in S/4HANA. HCM in S/4HANA is intended as a bridge to give customers additional time to move to SAP SuccessFactors. Consistency with the Business Suite is ensured by applying the same data model.

Therefore, no new or updated business processes are developed here. Some Fiori apps will be provided over time, including analytical pages ‚Äì check out the Fiori Apps Library and filter for Product Suite SAP S/4HANA and the LoB ‚ÄúHuman Resources‚Äù.

Investments into intelligent scenarios are entirely focused on SuccessFactors, which is one of the frontrunners for Generative AI ‚Äì more details here: Generative AI with SAP

The HCM functionality in S/4HANA is licensed - both in private cloud and on-premise - via engine licenses with an ‚Äúemployee‚Äù metric, no longer by core named user licenses. SAP thus paves the way also commercially for the transition to SuccessFactors, where the same commercial model applies

Business Function for SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA (H4S4_1)

  • HCM in S/4HANA (Business function H4S4_1) is available in S/4HANA starting from release 2022
  • All HCM customers with S/4HANA Release 2022 or 2023 must activate H4S4_1 business function (docu) in transaction SFW5

‚ÄìA system S/4HANA Release 2022 or 2023  without H4S4_1 business function activation runs as an HCM S/4HANA Compatibility Pack

  • Pay attention: H4S4_1 business function activation is irreversible. It deprecates some HCM (PA, TM & PY) functionalities normally applied in on-premise edition (SAP ERP HCM, HCM S/4HANA Compatibility Pack), so the activation must be object of a Conversion/Upgrade Project to evaluate impact of used deprecated functionalities and implement suggested alternative solutions
    • SAP Note 3091160 - SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì General Approach and Strategy - SAP for Me contains the lists of deprecated functionalities and suggest alternative solutions to apply
    • Readiness Check run gives informations about deprecated functionalities
  • This business function is exclusively available to customers who have purchased a separate license to use SAP Human Capital Management for SAP S/4HANA
  • With the release of S/4HANA 2025 and higher, this business function will be activated by default. Therefore, the new functionality for HCM for S/4HANA is available for all HCM customers.
  • Using the so-called HR mini-master in an SAP S/4HANA system, only to define business partner in the "Employee" role in a non-HCM system, does not require licensing SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA, even if the Business Function H4S4_1 is active. Please refer to SAP Note 3369920.

entry.title: Introducing ‚ÄúPrograms‚Äù in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
When organizations go through large-scale transformations, they often run many projects at once, each with its own goals, teams, and timelines. Keeping track of everything, understanding how these projects connect, and reporting on overall progress can quickly become a challenge.

That‚Äôs why SAP Cloud ALM now introduces a new capability called Programs, designed to make it easier to manage and oversee multiple related projects in one place.

What Is a Program?

Each Program represents a larger transformation initiative, and underneath it, you can have multiple projects that contribute to that initiative. Think of a Program as a big umbrella that brings together several related projects.

A Program gives you one central view to see how all your projects are doing, both individually and together. It helps you stay organized and aligned across teams and regions.

What Has Changed

Previously, when you launched Projects and Setup tile, you accessed everything under a single Projects tab.

Now, that tab has been renamed to ‚ÄúProjects/Programs.‚Äù This reflects the new capability we‚Äôve added, the ability to manage not only individual projects but also Programs, which can bring together multiple related projects under one umbrella.

To access Programs, simply click the small dropdown menu next to ‚ÄúProjects/Programs‚Äù in the navigation area. From there, select Programs, and you‚Äôll be able to view, create, and manage all your programs in one place.

 

Why Programs Are Useful

With the new Programs feature, you can:

  • Group related projects together under one Program.
  • Track overall progress across all projects in that Program.
  • See detailed project information when you need to dig deeper.
  • Run analytics and reports at the Program level to get a complete picture of how your transformation is progressing.

In short, Programs make it easier to see the ‚Äúbig picture‚Äù while still keeping control over the details.

How to Use Programs

Using Programs in SAP Cloud ALM is simple and intuitive:

  • Creating a Program
    • Users with Project Manage authorization can create a new Program.
    • Enter a Title (mandatory) and an optional Description.
    • After saving, the Program appears in the Programs list. 
  • Assigning Projects to a Program
    • When editing a project, you can now assign it to a Program.
    • The Program assignment is optional, each project can belong to zero or one Program.
    • You can also remove a project from a Program at any time.
    • The Program information is visible in both the Project and the Program levels. 
  • Viewing Projects in a Program
    • In the Program Details view, you‚Äôll see a list of all projects assigned to that Program.
    • Projects are displayed with their names, statuses, and timelines(future roadmap), giving you a quick overview of how each project contributes to the overall initiative.
    • Archived projects that are part of the Program will appear as display-only items, they cannot be edited.
    • If a private project is part of the Program but you don‚Äôt have access rights to it, it will be shown as ‚ÄúPrivate Project‚Äù, keeping visibility balanced with access control.
  • API Support
    • You can also manage Programs using the public Projects API available on the SAP API Business Hub:
      • Create or edit Programs
      • Assign or remove a Program from a Project
      • Retrieve single or multiple Programs

 

 

What‚Äôs Coming Next

This is just the beginning. The Programs feature will continue to evolve as part of our roadmap.
In the future, we plan to enhance Programs with:

  • Improved analytics and reporting, so you can track progress more effectively.
  • Grouping of scopes to better organize work within programs.
  • The ability to manage requirements and risks directly at the Program level, and connect them with related projects.

These upcoming improvements will make Programs an even more powerful tool for managing complex transformations.

 

A Real-World Example

Let‚Äôs take a global SAP S/4HANA rollout as an example.

Imagine your company is rolling out S/4HANA across multiple countries Germany, the US, and Singapore, for instance. Each country has its own project to handle local configurations, integrations, and timelines.

By creating a Program for the entire global rollout, you can bring all these projects together under one structure.

  • Each project focuses on the specific work needed in its country.
  • The Program gives you one central place to monitor all of them helping you track overall progress, identify risks, and report on the global transformation effort.

With this approach, you get both clarity and control  you can see how each country is progressing, and at the same time, understand the overall health of your entire global S/4HANA transformation.

 

In Summary

The new Programs capability in SAP Cloud ALM helps you manage large-scale transformations more efficiently. By grouping related projects under one Program, you can gain better visibility, simplify reporting, and coordinate work across your organization.

And with planned enhancements for analytics, scope grouping, and risk and requirement management, Programs will soon become a key part of how you run your most important transformation initiatives.

entry.title: Re: Effortless SAPUI5 Patch Management: Introducing the New SAPUI5 Runtime Repository
entry.content:
Hi @RalphBoehme and @Marian_Zeis,

instead of the generic MIME repository there are now dedicated tables  that are optimized for this purpose.
These are tables with name /UI5/RREP_*. The runtime uses the view /UI5/RT_REPO_V.

The new repository supports having multiple major versions installed permanently. I.e. whenever there is a new major version 2.x, the system will be able to serve 1.x and 2.x in parallel. Please understand that I can't share any timelines regarding this.
It will not be able to have multiple minor versions installed in parallel, since the general strategy of UI5 is to be backward compatible.
To support zero downtime updates, the system can host multiple patch versions temporarily. This allows to apply patches to a system while users are logged on and have the old patch version still running in their browsers.

Best regards
Matthias

entry.title: Re: üì¢ Survey: ABAP Naming Conventions
entry.content:
Hi All,
as I see naming conventions not only cover the name of repository objects, but data declarations with DATA keyword and name of local classes in Local Type (includes) etc.

ATC is a post-processing tool, when everything is ready to transport anyway. Getting feedback at that point for me is too late in the process. If a developer starts to do fixes based on ATC checks at that stage, there is a possibility to introduce bugs via rewriting code or the alpha test by developer has to be redone again. This is a very common issue today already.

For me as developer it would be important to get feedback by the compiler during edition about the names of DATA and local classes, and even CDS property names like using Amount postfix and similar described in the VDM Naming conventions etc.
Forex as today it is already in place on BTP ABAP Environment, when defining RAP Cross BOs, the compiler tells you to use the abbreviation keyword in Behavior definition and a shorter name for your for association otherwise it will not work. So the validation happens during edition.

  • I would go creating a new repository object called "NAMC" Naming convention or similar as source code
  • Every new package or software component therefore will have a new property/field: Naming Convention/NAMC
  • It could be assigned on software component or package level
  • If it is not maintained in child package, it will inherit from parent package with dynamic lookup (like when pulling packages with gCTS in ABAP Cloud we have the Transport Layer: $SPL showing the transport layer is inherited from parent)
  • Upon creating structure packages or components, a central Naming Convention variant is defaulted, so this will reduce the maintenance costs to minimum, you deal then with naming conventions when you want to differ from the central rules
  • The persona maintaining such is the development architect/lead developer, and a separate PFCG role is deserved here

This would be great :), at least an idea to brainstorm or refine in further üòä.

I am really happy with  the lot of initiatives regarding development and tooling by SAP nowadays. As a lead developer I feel supported better and better üëç

entry.title: Re: üì¢ Survey: ABAP Naming Conventions
entry.content: @Attila "ATC is a post-processing tool" this holds not true in all cases, there is also the developer scenario, whre the developer initiates the ATC check right from ADT.  This is the more common use case in our scenarios. We expect the developers to check during coding/code-review, so when the code is ready to transport there should be no findings anymore (as this in contained in our DoD).

entry.title: Re: Customer Order // Reference field mandatory
entry.content:
Create a custom incompleteness procedure and assign this to the relevant document and omit BSTKD.

The SSCUI ID for this configuration activity is: 101189

Your functional lead should be able to guide you on configuring this and what other fields should be included/omitted based on the clients needs.

entry.title: Re: From Application Logging to Cloud Logging: Service Innovation Guide
entry.content:
Hi @Hariharan-Gandhi ,

one quarter later, is there already a timeline for API access? That would be very useful and would avoid the need to create logging tables.

entry.title: Re: üì¢ Survey: ABAP Naming Conventions
entry.content: WRoeckelein yes, that is the ideal case and good that a developer team can reach that level and used to it to execute manually the ATC Checks on regular base during implementation üôÇ. However that is not enforced on any manner until the transport happens, where automated ATC checks are running. ATC Checks also do many other things, not only naming conventions are validated. ATC is really slow, so I would not like it to do it after writing few lines or finishing a method in a local RAP behavior pool or implementing an interface method. That is truly a painful wait time already today.

entry.title: Re: How can I set up receiver Cost Center Characteristic...
entry.content:
hi, 

Configuration in KEPA (CO-PA)
Define Characteristics and Value Fields in KEPA customizing using transaction KEA0 or via IMG path:
Controlling ‚Üí Profitability Analysis ‚Üí Basic Settings ‚Üí Define Characteristic.

Include Cost Center characteristic in your operating concern.

Assign source fields from costing or FI documents that contain cost centers.
